Over time, I've come to believe that
almost every technical issue we deal
with in Unreal can be grouped in one of
these four broad categories. Firstly, we
have implementation and performance
issues. These are just your classic bugs
or inefficiencies and how systems are
built. That includes both things that
don't work and things that work poorly
like frame drops, memory leaks,
incorrect logic, etc. Uh then there's
engines and system integration. This is
where things break between different
systems, version upgrades, platform
specific edge cases, or issues caused by
third party SDKs or plugins. These are
tricky because they often involve Unreal
internals or external factors outside of
your own immediate codebase. Uh the
third bucket is technical debt and
architecture issues. These are the
long-term pain points. Maybe you've
built something that worked once, but
now it's fragile, hard to debug, or
impossible to extend. This kind of debt
tends to accumulate slowly until it
explodes under pressure. And finally,
scope creep, which where the technical
issues arise not from broken code most
often, but from shifting requirements.
The feature keeps growing, the
complexity spirals, and suddenly you're
firefighting on all fronts just trying
to keep up with what the system now
needs to do. So why does it matter which
category your problem falls into?
Because each type of problem usually
involves a different group of people
that have to help you solve it for
implementation or performance issues or
anything related to engine and systems
integration. You're often working
directly with other engineers. Uh
reading through their code, checking
logs, profiling, stepping through engine
source, etc. But when it comes to
technical debt or scope creep, solving
the problem is only part of the
challenge and the other part is
convincing somebody else that it needs
to be solved at all. These kinds of
problems typically involve conversations
with producers, leads, stakeholders,

we found that the first occurrence began

A common issue we identified in this
project was that using blueprint nodes

On the surface, it's convenient node,
but under the hood, it creates a new

So, the fix, we moved the logic to C++,
retrieved the components once, and used
a T inline component array on the stack
to avoid heat allocations. We also began
pre-reserving memory for arrays and used
T inline allocators where possible.
Again, keeping memory on the stack
instead of the heap.

So when you're facing an issue,
especially one that seems mysterious or
intermittent, your best bet is to strip
the problem down to just the systems
that you're testing. Remove as many
variables as possible. If you can
replicate the issue in a clean, minimal
test map or isolated module, you're far
more likely to understand what's really
going on. This also makes it easier for

Fixing a problem isn't just about
writing code. It's about understanding
the impact of your fix, making sure it
doesn't cause new issues or that it
integrates well with the rest of the
system. In this last section, we'll look
at strategies and best practices to
approach fixing problems effectively and
safely because identifying the issue is
only half the battle and delivering a
solid fix on the problem is ultimately
what matters.
When it comes to fixing issues, it's
important to understand that every fix
has a blast radius. In other words, the
potential impact or fallout from that
change that it could have on other
systems. Even the best intentioned fixes
can unintentionally break other parts of
the code base. So before making sweeping
changes to fix a bug, it's best you
assess the risk involved in actually
making that fix. There's a few key
factors to consider. The visibility,
which is, you know, is the issue or fix
something that users or clients are
going to directly see? The more visible
it is, the higher the risk if something
actually goes wrong. Complexity. How
intertwined is this code or system that
we're changing? If it's tightly coupled
with heaps of other systems, even a
small change could have big consequences
that you might not be aware of. Do we
fully understand how that system works?
And if not, the risk increases because
unexpected side effects become more
likely. And lastly, timing. I'll be
close to a milestone or a major release
because changes late in the cycle carry
more risk since there's less time for us
to test and fix those new issues.
Understanding these factors helps you
make smarter decisions about how to
approach fixes. Whether that means more
testing, incremental rollouts, or
involving more team members.
So, when selecting how to fix an issue,
it's crucial to align your strategy with
the level of risk involved. For low-risk
issues where the impact is minimal and
you have confidence in your fix, it's
usually fine to just proceed directly,
make the change, then test it thoroughly
yourself to confirm that the fixes
behavior is expected and doesn't cause
any side effects. But for medium risk
issues where the fix affects more
complex or visible systems, a more
cautious approach may be needed. Make
sure to perform thorough testing and
ideally have other team members review
your changes or involve your QA team
early. It's also important to document
what you've done as this helps track the
change later on. For high-risisk issues
where the blast radius could be large or
the system is critical, it's best to
apply mitigation strategies. It could be

roll out of that fix. It's it allows you
to enable or disable the change quickly
without a full release. Uh which is very

changes.
It also creates friction for your whole
team, and onboarding new engineers can

A critical bug fix that isn't yet merged
upstream and is blocking you. A core
engine limitation that is in your way of
your game's essential feature. A proven

validated performance gains. Or if

tech platform where you'll own the

I'd recommend following best practices.

only modify base engine files if it's
actually necessary. Try to isolate
changes into new files if possible or
